content: The EPA believes there should be a higher rate of NSR permits for new or expanded facilities. The CAA requires preconstruction review and permits for major modifications or new sources of air pollution. States with EPA-approved SIPs must approve construction or modifications to ensure compliance with NAAQS. The NSR process ensures proposed sources won't violate NAAQS or exceed air pollution limits under PSD regulations. The New Source Review (NSR) process is triggered for new sources emitting 100 tons annually of any criteria air pollutant or causing a significant increase in emissions. Requirements depend on whether the source is subject to PSD or non-attainment provisions, with installation of Best Available Control Technology (BACT) or Lowest Achievable Emission Rate (LAER) mandated. Few preconstruction permits have been issued to coal-fired power plants under NSR. Preconstruction permits for coal-fired power plants have been limited, which is not surprising given the steady capacity of 300,000 MW in the U.S. over the last decade. Emissions trends show a static situation for coal-fired capacity, with NOx emissions remaining constant but a significant drop in SO2 emissions in 1995 due to the acid rain control program. This program required 111 power plants to reduce emissions by 30% and install Low-NOx burners. The EPA required 111 power plants to reduce emissions by 30% and install Low-NOx burners. SO2 emissions decreased from 10 million tons in 1990 to 5.3 million tons in 1995, while NOx emissions decreased by 0.4 million tons in 1996. However, some reductions were offset by increases in emissions from other plants, indicating a slippage in overall emission reductions. In 1998, a new standard of 0.15 lb. of NOx per million Btu was set but was challenged in court. The D.C.
